subject: Re: [junit] Ignore without recompile?

messageBody:
Ideally you would have some separation of concerns in your code and
tests such that the tests which interact with your database have a
common attribute (all named Db....Test.java, or all are located in
**/db/**.java) which you could use in your FileSet to specify which
tests to run.

Without this separation, it certainly makes grouping tests like you're
trying to do much more complicated. (TestNG has more "test grouping"
features so you may want to look into it.)

As for automating the testing, I'd suggest that you look into a real
Continuous Integration server like CruiseControl or Continuum. Cron is
great for simple stuff but most people benefit from real CI.

Wayne

On 3/7/07, niklassaers <niklassaers@...> wrote:
> Hi guys,
> for our project me and a friend are using JUnit heavily. Our
> application is a client that collects data and a backend that
> organizes and analyses it. Lately we have started to use JUnit tests
> to ensure that our database is sane, and these tests take quite a
> while. Now, I don't actually need to know that the database is still
> sane every time I recompile, so I'd like to ignore them. But adding
> and removing @Ignore's will fill up our CVS repo quickly. Besides,
> I've also set up a box to run tests from cron, and I'd like to i.e. do
> most tests every 15 minutes (gives me a nice little pop-up when
> something breaks) and only run the DB sanity every four hours. How can
> I make a testing schedule? Should I do this through ANT? Can I make a
> property-file for JUnit that checks if a certain time has elapsed? At
> the moment my fileset is just <include name="**/test/**/*.java"/> I
> hope I don't have to make individual ant targets and list the files
> manually! :-) What are my options?
>
> Cheers
